subject: RE: [junit] Re: Help,what's wrong with my TDD practice in my daily life?
msgSnippet: Or worse, I ve seen this happen: Write code1 Write code2  Refactor code1/code2 into code3
messageBody:
Or worse, I've seen this happen:



Write code1

Write code2

<realize a refactoring is possible>

Refactor code1/code2 into code3

<happy with the result, now we write the test>

Write test3

<test3 passes; happy with the result>



This looks like everything is fine, but they didn't realize that their test passed because they wrote it wrong and/or their test doesn't really cover all the functionality of the code. These are the risks of writing the tests after the code.



When people just can't get themselves to write tests first, I tell them to do a little exercise with the code once they have written their tests and they are satisfied that they work: comment each line of code out one at a time and re-run the tests. At least one test should fail each time and they should also look at the error information to be sure that the test failed for the expected reason. It's also good to go the other direction and try to make each test fail one at a time. A test that has never failed in its existence is a risky test.



..David..

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> , "CÃ©dric Beust â(tm)"" <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> Hi James,
>
> On 9/10/07, James Carr <james.r.carr@...> wrote:
>
> > On 9/10/07, you wrote:
> > >
> > > Just like everything else, use TDD sparingly. I understand
you are
> > > currently doing this as an exercise, so it's healthy to take
it to
> > > extremes and do everything by the book in order to learn,
but in your
> > > real work, use your judgment and decide for yourself when
you are
> > > indeed writing too much code, in which case it's probably
safer to go
> > > the usual route (get your code to work, then write tests for
it).
> > >
> > > The downside of TDD is that you can end up writing a lot of
tests for
> > > business code that you quickly throw away and rewrite, so
the amount
> > > of churn can be quite high.
> > >
> >
> > I disagree. When I've found something difficult to write test
first
> > I've always done a spike, then delete the code and rewrote it
test
> > first. I've always found the result to be a lot more cleaner,
> > especially since I wind up cleaning up the code anyway when I
used to
> > write tests around them.
> >
> > I'd rather have my business code tested rather than not test it
under
> > the assumption it will one day be thrown away. ;)
>
> Well, I never suggested not writing tests, I was just saying that
> sometimes, it's okay to write your tests once you're done with the
> business code.
>
> Here is a scenario I've seen happen fairly often:
>
> Write test1
> Write code1
> Write test2
> Write code2
>
> Then a refactoring comes to mind and you realize you don't need
code1
> and code2 any more, so you write code3, and suddenly, you find
> yourself having to refactor (or throw away) both test1 and test2.
>
> I was simply suggesting that sometimes, the following flow works
better:
>
> Write code1
> Write code2
> <realize a refactoring is possible>
> Refactor code1/code2 into code3
> <happy with the result, now we write the test>
> Write test3
>
> Net result: two less tests to write.

Sometimes that sequence ends there and sometimes it becomes:

Write code1
Write code2
<realize a refactoring is possible>
Refactor code1/code2 into code3
<happy with the result, now we write the test>
Write test3
Shit. Test3 doesn't pass
<unhappy with result>

Everybody has to find their balance. For me, it's just faster and
less frustating to have tests when I refactor.

Michael Feathers
www.objectmentor.com
